text:
1-Riverside Drive, at about 123rd Street, showing Grant's Tomb. The tomb of Ulysses S. Grant was built by John H. Duncan, architect, by popular subscription at a cost of $600,000. It stands 150 ft by 90 ft. square and is built of granite from quarries in Maine and New Hampshire. Ground for the tomb was broken on Grant's Birthday April 27, 1891, the corner stone being laid April 27, 1892.
Copyright 1897 by A. Loeffler.

2-the same
Copyright 1897 by Johnston
1897

Riverside, at about 123rd Street, showing Grant's Tomb, looking north.

Detroit Photographic Co.
Copyright 1900

folder: Riverside Park & Ulysses S. Grant's Tomb., Manhattan, NY

February 13, 1901.

Gift of Randall Comfort.

(1)
North (Hudson) River, skyline, north from West 116th (right) to West 130th Streets, showing (right center) the Tomb of General U.S. Grant, and to its left, International House. Also shown (left) is the landing of the Fort Lee (N.J.) Ferry and the excursion boat "Trojan".
1925.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at a later date, showing in addition Riverside Church and to its right; towers of Union Theological Seminary.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, as view No. 2.

P. L. Sperr.
June 8, 1934.

folder: Riverside Drive & Van Siclen Avenue, Manhattan, NY
original_title: Manhattan: Riverside Drive - Van Siclen Avenue
text:
(1) Riverside Baptist Church, (Riverside Drive at the S.E. corner of West 122nd Street) and Grant's Tomb (Riverside Drive, north of West 122nd Street), as seen from the Hudson River.

September 16, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) A closer view. Also shown paralleling the rivers edge, are the tracks of the New York Central R.R.

September 16, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) A view solely of the afore-mentioned church.

September 16, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

Riverside Park at 104th Street. View, southward in No. 1 and northward in No. 2, showing the marginal lands that will be landscaped by the Park Department in 1936-37 as a part of the West Side Improvement Project. In the first, at West 96th Street appears the well known U.S.S. Illinois, while the second shows Grants Tomb, the George Washington Bridge and the Riverside Memorial Church in its background.

June 17, 1934.
View 2:--June 11, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
(1) site of General Ulysses Grant's Tomb. Riverside Drive. National Capitol Washington, D.C. (2) ✔ Riverside Drive, East Side between 123rd and 127th Streets. Shown is Grants Tomb.
